question: http://www.professionalabstracts.com/ilc2014/planner/index.php?go=abstract&action=abstract_show&absno=3276&HEPATITIS B AND C VIRUS PROMOTE CROSSTALK BETWEEN HYPOXIA AND GLUCOCORTICOID SIGNALLING PATHWAYS TO RE-PROGRAMME HEPATOCYTE METABOLISM AND TO EVADE HOST INTERFERONS	PrintG.K. Wilson1, L.W. Meredith1, D. Greenland2, L. Mailly3, D. Tennant4, M. Ashcroft5, T.F. Baumert3, J.W. Tomlinson6, S.G. Hubscher7, F.V. Eeden2, P. Balfe1, J.A. McKeating11Centre for Human Virology, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, 2Department of Biomedical Science, Sheffield University, Sheffield, United Kingdom, 3Institut National de la Santé et de la Recherche Médicale, Université de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France, 4School of Cancer Sciences, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, 5Centre for Cell Signalling and Molecular Genetics, University College London, London, 6Centre for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolism, University of Birmingham, 7Department of Cellular Pathology, Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham, Birmingham, United KingdomE-mail: g.k.***@****Background and aims: Chronic viral infection of the liver is a global health problem. At least 500 million individuals are infected with hepatitis B (HBV) and C (HCV) viruses, which cause liver disease including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Interferon based therapies have limited efficacy in the majority of subjects and recent reports demonstrating significant interferon stimulated gene expression (ISG) in chronic hepatitis suggest that these viruses have evolved mechanisms to evade the anti-viral effects of interferon. Our aim is to understand the impact of HBV and HCV stabilization of hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) on viral persistence in the hepatic environment.Methods: We used a variety of in vitro (hepatocytes/hepatoma lines) and in vivo (VHL null zebra fish, SCID-upA chimeric liver mice and viral infected human liver tissue) models to study the effect of HBV and HCV infection on HIF and glucocorticoid signalling on hepatocyte metabolism and response to interferons.Results: HBV and HCV infection stabilize HIF-1α and activate glucocorticoid receptor (GR) transcriptional responses associated with gluconeogenesis and blunt the cellular response to a range of interferons. GR antagonists restore the anti-viral efficacy of alpha and lambda interferons.Conclusions: Our findings uncover a new pathway for hepatitis viruses to utilise the hypoxic pathway to persist by reprogramming cellular metabolism and evading host innate immune responses. These studies highlight new therapeutic targets for treating chronic viral hepatitis.Assigned speakers:Garrick Wilson , University of Birmingham , Birmingham , United KingdomAssigned in sessions:10.04.2014, 09:00-18:00, Poster, 7A - VIRAL HEPATITIS: HEPATITIS B & D - EXPERIMENTAL, Poster Exhibition
